157.title:  "Conversation avec Boilet et Taniguchi"
157.author: Julien Bastide
157.appears_in: p. 54-61 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 10 (Apr. 2004).
notes: (Le Manga d'Auteur)

Begins: "Le premier est le seul auteur de bandes dessinées français ayant réussi à s'implanter au Japon; le second est l'auteur japonais que tout le monde s'arrache depuis le succès en France de Quartier lointain, Alph'art du meilleur scénario au Festival d'Angoulême 2003. Frédéric Boilet et Jirô Taniguchi se sont rencontrés en 1991, et n'ont depuis cessé de travailler ensemble, oeuvrant pour une meilleure connaissance de la bande dessinée japonaise en France, et réciproquement. Retour sur douze ans d'amitié et deux collaborations."

English summary (from p. 127): "Conversation with Boilet and Taniguchi. One is the only French author to have succeeded in establishing a following in Japan; the other a Japanese author in great demand since the success of Quartier Lointain. Frédéric Boilet and Jirô Taniguchi met in 1991 and have since constantly worked to make French comics better known in Japan and vice versa. Julien Bastide orchestrates a dialogue between the two, going back over twelve years of friendship and two co-signed works."
Includes illustrations.

162.title:  "Conversation avec Lorenzo Mattotti"
162.author: Gilles Ciment & Jean-Pierre Mercier
162.appears_in: p. 46-56 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 9 (Oct. 2003). Begins: "Illustrateur et affichiste parmi les plus demandés, Mattotti a su imposer un style immédiatement reconnaissable. Il poursuit parallèlement son travail d'auteur de bandes dessinées, sans suivre d'autre règle que celle de son désir et de sa curiosité. Deux albums récents (Dr Jeckyll et Mr Hyde, Le Bruit du Givre) et plusieurs rééditions lui ont assuré une fort présence dans les librairies depuis quelques mois. 9e Art ne pouvait laisser passer l'occasion de saluer un maître qui a tenu toutes les promesses de Feux, l'album programmatique paru en 1986."
notes: English summary (from p. 126): "A Conversation with Lorenzo Mattotti. Interviewed by Gilles Ciment and Jean-Pierre Mercier, the great Italian artist evokes his comics debut in depth, his acquaintance with Jerry Kramsky and the Valvoline group, but also his approach to painting, posters and comics. He pays particular attention to the genesis of his two last albums: Doctor Jeckyll and Mister Hyde after Stevenson (Casterman) and Le Bruit du Givre (éd. du Seuil)."
Includes bibliography.

166.title:  "Conversation avec Will Eisner"
166.author: Jean-Paul Jennequin
166.appears_in: p. 86-94 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 7 (Jan. 2002).
notes: (Will Eisner)

Begins: "À près de 85 ans, Will Eisner, invité du Festival d'Angoulême 2002, continue d'aligner des albums témoignant à la fois d'un métier très sûr et d'une grande liberté d'inspiration. Entre fiction, reportage et autobiographie, le père du légendaire Spirit élargit un oeuvre qui est l'une des plus considérables de l'histoire des comics, en terms d'innovation, de diversité et d'influence."

English summary (from p. 151): "Conversation with Will Eisner. Will Eisner, almost 85 years old, will be the guest of the International Festival of Comics in Angoulême in January 2002. Jean-Paul Jennequin asks him about the evolution of his technique, of layout, of the importance of text in graphic novels, and about the concessions to be made to readership and marketing. The father of the Spirit sums up his conceptions of the art to which he personally has contributed so much."

258.title:  Conversations with Comic Artists. Chester Brown : Conversations
258.author: edited by Dominick Grace and Eric Hoffman ; annotated by Chester Brown.
notes: (Conversations with Comic Artists)
Includes index.
"The early 1980s saw a revolution in mainstream comics
in subject matter, artistic integrity, and creators' rights

as new methods of publishing and distribution broadened the possibilities. Among those artists utilizing these new methods, Chester Brown quickly developed a cult following due to the undeniable quality and originality of his Yummy Fur. Chester Brown: Conversations collects interviews covering all facets of the cartoonist's long career and includes several pieces from now-defunct periodicals and fanzines. Brown was among a new generation of artists whose work dealt with decidedly nonmainstream subjects. By the 1980s comics were not just for kids anymore and subsequent censorious attacks by parents concerned about the more salacious material being published by the major publishers
subjects that routinely included adult language, realistic violence, drug use, and sexual content

began to roil the industry. Yummy Fur came of age during this storm and its often-offensive content, including dismembered, talking penises, led to controversy and censorship. With Brown's highly unconventional adaptations of the Gospels, and such comics memoirs as The Playboy and I Never Liked You, Brown gradually moved away from the surrealistic, humor-oriented strips toward autobiographical material far more restrained and elegiac in tone than his earlier strips. This work was followed by Louis Riel, Brown's critically acclaimed comic book biography of the controversial nineteeth-century Canadian revolutionary, and Paying for It, his best-selling memoir on the life of a john."

(Thunderbolts)
"Contains material originally published in magazine form as Thunderbolts #152-157."

"Luke Cage's team of hardened super-convicts are in search of redemption, but only find a series of horrific threats! First, at the request of Steve Rogers, Cage's crew must deal with the crazy creatures unleashed by M.O.D.O.K. and the Leaders' Scorched Earth doomsday scenario! With the squad a member short, Cage uses his pull to recruit another prisoner to duty. Will the Thunderbolts accept this amazingly powerful (and headstrong) new member, or will this heavy-duty wild card destroy the balance of power? Also includes a tale starring Man-Thing; and Luke Cage and Dr. Strange team up to recruit a new supernatural member, but is her fearsome nature too much even for the T-Bolts; plus, what happens when Warden Walker takes the recruiting efforts into his own hands?"

Summary (from OCLC): One of the main problems facing the Old West's inhabitants was the lack of women in frontier territories. Entire towns were populated only by men, while many unmarried young women languished on the east coast. To remedy that situation, marriages were arranged by mail. And now we find a reluctant Lucky Luke in charge of protecting a convoy of brides on their way west. Could he, too, be in danger of finding a wife?
